YANG DI-PERTUAN NEGARA'S
SPEECH
(Debate on the Address)
(Second Day)


    Order read for resumption of adjourned debate on Question [19th December, 1961],

    'That the following Address in reply to the speech of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara be agreed to:-

    "We, the Legislative Assembly of the State of Singapore, express our thanks to the Yang di-Pertuan Negara for the speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the opening of the present session of this Assembly.".'.-(The Deputy Prime Minister).

    Question again proposed.

Column: 2583



2.39 p.m.

    Mr Speaker: Has the Member for Bras Basah completed her speech?

    Madam Hoe Puay Choo (Bras Basah)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to continue from where I left off yesterday.

    Yesterday, the Member for Stamford made certain allegations in regard to women's problems. I would like to ask her whether what she said came really from her heart. She should not have made such allegations because she knows full well that women's problems cannot be solved in a very short space of time and that they are related to the general problems of our society. A division in the Left-wing camp is not in anybody's interest and it can only be favourable to the British colonial rulers who can then prolong their colonial rule and influence here, because we know they are rather cunning and wish to preserve their prestige and position here, and they will adopt all means to achieve this objective. Therefore, we should be careful to see that we are not fooled by them. I wish to tell them that if they dare dream of resuming their good old times here, we will unite together and struggle against them.

    I also appeal to Members of the Barisan Sosialis not to smear the P.A.P. and accuse it of working in collusion with the British colonialists. If they see any mistakes and defects in us, then they should point them out so as to enable us to rectify them in the interest and happiness of the people of Singapore. Mr Speaker, Sir, this is our hope.

    Mr Tee Kim Leng (Pasir Panjang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Bras Basah says that the P.A.P. has been against colonial rule. But we have found that the leadership of the P.A.P. are not the type who does such things. Outwardly they want to show that they are anti-colonial fighters but, in fact, they are closely associated with the colonialists. I know this because I was with them for more than

Column: 2584

two years. From what I saw of them and from their words and actions, I came to know them well. They only preach without putting into effect what they say, That is why today they are in such a sad position. If the leadership want to obtain freedom and rights for the people of Singapore from the colonialists, we will support them in this struggle. Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to touch on the many broadcasts that the Prime Minister has put over Radio Singapore. It appears that Radio Singapore has now become a propaganda instrument of the P.A.P. Today the leadership of the P.A.P. do not dare face the people to explain their policies on merger and on other aspects. They have to hide now behind radio forums to tell, their stories. But the people have lost faith in them. Whenever the Prime Minister is heard over the Radio, the people switch off their radios or they tune in to other radio stations to listen to other programmes. In his several broadcasts over Radio Singapore, the Prime Minister told the people certain stories, but the people lost interest in them. So his broadcasts have had no effect on the people because they found many contradictions in them. In his second talk he said that many of the Communists are from the Chinese-educated. His intention was to smear the Chinese-educated and to get the Malay-educated, the English-educated or the Indian-educated to be suspicious of the Chinese-educated. This is very irresponsible. Why did the Prime Minister say in his twelve talks that there are also Communists in the English-educated -

    Mr Speaker: Order. We are now debating the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's speech and the Government's policy as contained in that speech. We are certainly not debating any broadcasts made by the Prime Minister. If the hon. Member can indicate which part of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's speech has particular reference to these broadcasts, then I will let him continue. If he cannot, then, of course, he is completely irrelevant,

Column: 2585



    Mr Tee Kim Leng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I did touch on the Prime Minister's broadcasts over Radio Singapore. It is because Radio Singapore is under the control of the Ministry of Culture. However, Radio Singapore should serve the purpose of the people and not the purpose of a political Party. That is why I feel it necessary to point out that the PAP, has been using Radio Singapore for its own interests. And that is why I touched on it just now.

    Mr Speaker: Order. Up to that point, the hon. Member is perfectly in order. But if he debates the details of those broadcasts, then he is out of order.

    Mr Tee Kim Leng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the P.A.P. Government has been saying that it is a pro-labour Government. It has been telling this to people everywhere. Let us see whether it is correct. The Government told us that it cancelled the registration of four trade union federations because it was the decision of the Internal Security Council. But lately I have found out that this is not correct because the decision to cancel the registration of the four trade union federations was not from the Internal Security Council but from the Government itself. It is only because the Government was afraid of the growing strength of the workers, and that the trade union movement would be a danger to their political position and power that they took such a decision Recently the Government resorted to action against the workers. This kind of act is not different from what the colonialists did in the past. Let me give some examples. For instance, the strike at Robinson's. When it took place the Government used the police against the workers. Some of the staff of the People's Association protested against certain of their members being sacked. They staged a strike. They protested against the unreasonable action by the authorities concerned, and against the People's Association engaging new workers. For these two reasons, they went on strike. But the P.A.P. Government warned them that if they were not

Column: 2586

loyal to the P.A.P. Government, then they would be sacked. This is not correct because the People's Association has its own constitution and is main tained by public funds, and much of these funds comes from -

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education (Mr Lee Khoon Choy): Point of order. The Member seems to be reading like a parrot!

    Mr Speaker: The Member seems to be referring to his notes rather too much. But if he is going into the details of the People's Association strike, then again he is out of order for two reasons. The first is that that does not cover the general debate on Government policy, and, secondly, I think we have had an assurance that there is going to be a Commission of Inquiry into the People's Association. It is perhaps too premature for the Members to raise these points.

    Mr Tee Kim Leng(In Mandarin): I was only referring to the fact that the People's Association was established by the public through elections by this Assembly. Therefore, it is a public organisation. The P.A.P. has no right to make use of this organisation for its own purposes. That is why I mention the strike there. It is necessary for me to point out the cause of this strike and to show that though the Government has claimed to be pro-labour, it is, in fact, not so.

    Mr Speaker: Order. As I have indicated, we are now on Government policy. The hon. Member is perfectly correct when he mentions the People's Association in the context, as he alleges, that it is being used by the Government. But when he goes into details as to why there was a strike - or a so-called strike - and why the police were used, then I think he is going far away from the debate which is permitted on this Address. We are only dealing with Government policy.

    Mr Tee Kim Leng(In Mandarin): Because the Ministers of the P.A.P. have denied that there has been any strike in the People's Association, that

Column: 2587

is why I have to point out that in the report from the Ministry of Labour it is clearly stated that the strike at the People's Association has not been resolved. I will ask the Minister to explain whether or not there has been a strike at the People's Association.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the anti-labour policy of the P.A.P. Government is becoming clearer day by day. This can be seen from its actions and attitude toward several strikes recently. The Public Daily-Rated Employees' Unions Federation truly represents the workers in Government departments. Then why will the Government not recognise it and claim that only A.U.P.E. can represent these workers? By this, can the Government promote industrial peace and give any benefit to the workers? The strike by the Public Daily-Rated Employees' Unions Federation and its consequences, which caused much inconvenience to the people, should be borne by the Government. The Government, on the one hand, says that it is pro-labour but, on the other hand, it engages new workers to replace the workers on strike and has been helping the employers who are doing such things. The Government also used the police and military personnel to deal with the strikers, and used the police to beat up the workers. Are all these things what a pro-labour Government can do? During the strike we could see military personnel stationed at every street corner as though they were taking precautions against an enemy.

    Mr Lee Khoon Choy: Point of order. Is all this really relevant to the motion?

    Mr Speaker: I take it the hon. Member is indicating that the Government policy in using police against strikers is not a policy to be advocated. He cannot, of course, go into details.

    Mr Tee Kim Leng(In Mandarin): And to stop traffic and people from crossing the roads. Is this the behaviour of the so-called pro-labour Government?

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the P.A.P. Government professes that it adopts the policy of equal treatment for all streams of

Column: 2588

education, but in the past two years have they received the same equal treatment? How many Malay schools, Chinese schools, and Indian schools have been opened by the Government? The Government has not only not promoted vernacular education and has also obstructed its growth. Let me cite one example to show this. Recently in Pasir Panjang at the 4th m.s. Labrador School was opened by the Government. This school originally was a Tamil school and the playing field also belonged to this Tamil school. But now this site is being occupied by an English school. On one side of the road, the land is being used by an English school, and on the other side the land has been used for building a hall for an English school. Are these examples of equal treatment for all streams of education? In such a small area as Pasir Panjang, the Government has opened five English Schools but there is only one Indian school. Moreover, this Indian school was not built by the Government. It was built by the Indians who live there. It is an aided Indian School. There is only one Chinese school there. This Chinese School is not a Government Chinese School. It is an aided school. There is only one Malay school there. Therefore, from this we can see that the so-called equal treatment for all streams of education means giving aid to English schools only.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in May this year, there was unfortunately a big fire at Bukit Ho Swee. In this fire, tens of thousands of people lost their homes and their property. At that time the people of Singapore demonstrated their co-operative spirit and their love of mankind by giving whatever they had to the victims in order to relieve them. Now after half a year the problems of these fire victims are still not settled. Who should bear this responsibility? I believe everyone will be able to answer that. The Government should be held responsible for not solving the problems of the fire victims. The Government has not carried out its pledge to help the fire victims. What the Prime Minister

Column: 2589

and the Minister for National Development pledged to the victims has not been carried out. Mr Speaker, the Government has departed from its policy of helping the fire victims. In the first P.A.P. pamphlet, on page 6, the first line states it very clearly. Many of the victims of the Kampong Tiong Bahru fire will tell you that they are very eager to have a piece of land so that they can engage in their secondary production.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, what the P.A.P. has said has all been forgotten by it. It is true that it is very difficult to give every fire victim a piece of land. But has the Government seriously studied the housing problem of the fire victims of the Bukit Ho Swee fire? The answer is no. Every fire victim will tell you that the house rent is very high. The fire victims cannot afford to pay it. Most of the houses are of the expensive type and the rental is high. People who belong to the lower income group cannot afford to pay this high rental. When the fire occurred, these fire victims were forced by the Government to move into the new flats. The house rent is as follows - $40 for a one-room flat, and $55 for a two-room flat.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I think the hon. Member must have been here when we discussed details of this nature during the debate on the Estimates. I do not think he should go over all these details again to make his point. But in making his point, he can say that a debate on this matter took place during the Estimates, and that he does not wish to go into details again. We cannot have repetitions of this nature.

    Mr Tee Kim Leng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, for the purpose of the record, I hope I can touch in detail on the plight of the fire victims. I would like to know whether you, Mr Speaker, Sir, will allow me to do so.

    Mr Speaker: It will be, I think, completely full of details when we publish our Hansard. I think the hon. Member will find that those details will be found in Hansard. Those details are already on record.

Column: 2590



    Mr Tee Kim Leng(In Mandarin): The request by the fire victims has not been answered by the Government. The Government has not taken any clear-cut action in dealing with this matter. I hope it will give a very clear-cut answer to all the fire victims' requests, and take practical measures to help them resolve their difficulties.

    Mr Speaker, the people of Singapore are today facing all kinds of misfortunes. Tens of thousands of people are now in difficulties. For instance, the 25,000 dwellers in Toa Payoh are facing the threat of being evicted. The authorities concerned have not indicated what would be their compensation and their fate in future. There are also a few hundred families along the West Coast Road who have been asked by the Government to remove, because the Government intends to build a road there. Also the farmers living in Kampong Kembangan have suffered from flooding and have incurred a great loss. But the Government has not taken any steps to deal with these matters. The Government, if it is a responsible one, should negotiate and talk with the people concerned. It should discuss with their representatives and the organisations of the people with a view to solving their problems. But the Government is disregarding all this and is leaving the people in the lurch. Yet, on the other hand, the Government is talking about development, serving the people, how to benefit them and to improve their welfare.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the P.A.P. Government has promised to help the fishermen in various ways, such as helping them to buy motor-boats and fishing equipment and all kinds pf necessities. But I would ask the Government this how many fishermen has it helped? It has also promised to help them organised into co-operative societies. How many such co-operative societies have been formed as a result of help from the Government? Has the livelihood of the fishermen living in Pasir Panjang, Jurong, Katong and Siglap been improved or helped in any way by the Government? Many of them are still semi-unemployed. Why is it that they

Column: 2591

are in this present predicament? It is because the P.A.P. has increased the tax on petrol so that they have to spend more when buying petrol. Every time they go out to sea to fish, they will have to spend several dollars on petrol, irrespective of whether they can get any catch or not. In fact, they can hardly catch any fish at all. The Malay fishermen are suffering. Their livelihood is in a predicament. I would ask the Government whether it is prepared to help them to buy motor-boats. In fact, the P.A.P. Government has forgotten about this. The Minister for National Development has also forgotten about this. They have forgotten what they have promised in the P.A.P. pamphlet entitled, "The P.A.P. Five-Year Plan." They have entirely disregarded and neglected the poor people.

    Mr Teo Hock Guan (Changi): Mr Speaker, Sir, the situation the P.A.P. faced in 1959 and before that was different from the situation which the P.A.P. now faces. Sir, this change in the political scene is quick, but it is expected. Sir, we see the rise and fall of the P.A.P. In 1959 and 1960 we saw how the P.A.P. bullied the Opposition Members of the S.P.A. In 1961, Sir, we see how the P.A.P. Government works hand in hand with the S.P.A. members. Why is it that the political scene outside and inside this Assembly has changed? It is because the P.A.P. Government has changed its political ideology, from Left to Right, and because the P.A.P. Government has no sincerity in carrying out its promises. Sir, the P.A.P. leaders have swallowed all their promises which they put before the people during the general elections. Sir, I shall now comment on certain departments of the Government to show you how the P.A.P. has swallowed its promises. Sir, I come to the questions of profit tax and roads. I would like to bring these matters to the attention of the Government. They concern the lives of the people living in the rural areas. Some of the assessment rates in the rural areas have been increased unreasonably. Their Assemblymen, or the persons affected, have

Column: 2592

lodged their complaints with the department concerned, but as usual there is no reply. Sir, how can the relationship between the people and the civil servants be improved? The promise of the P.A.P. at first was to serve the poor people, but when they came to form the government, they taxed the poor people first. If the Government wants to construct any new kampong road's, it should bear in mind that the constituencies of the Opposition Party Assemblymen also need new kampong roads. I would like to remind the Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister, who is also the Chairman of the Urban and Rural Services Advisory Council, that the Council has approved a sum of $65,000 to metal the Koh Seck Lim Road in the Bedok Resettlement area. It was unanimously approved by the Council in January this year under the chairmanship of the Member for Upper Serangoon. The present Chairman, the hon. Member for Tampines, and I and some other P.A.P. Assemblymen who are on the Opposite side, were members of the Council. Sir, the work of this Council is very important. Any project approved by this Council must be carried out and work on the project is usually started immediately after the approval of the Council. Now it is already one year and the Government seems to have no intention to metal the Koh Seck Lim Road. Sir, the Bedok Resettlement area is densely populated; many vehicles move along the laterite roads. The place becomes very dusty and you can see a thick layer of dust covering everything, in houses and shops. The Ministers may not believe it, because they have never seen any laterite roads. Sir, this is not the attitude the Government should take because I am on this side. That is why they refuse to metal the road. Sir, during the general elections, the P.A.P. said - and I quote from "Speakers' Notes on Trade Unions":

    'As the political status of Singapore changes from that of a Colony to that of a self-governing State, so must the present colonial economy change to that of a national one.'

Column: 2593

It continued:

    'For the past 140 years our colonial economy was based on the export of cheap raw materials to Imperial England and the selling of its expensive manufactured products in the country. This gives employment to the people in England and so loss of capital from Singapore and Malaya.'

    Sir, this is what the P.A.P. said during the election. Sir, the economic status of Singapore has remained the same under the P.A.P.'s rule for 2½ years, and the situation has turned from had to worse. Today we can see not only Imperial England but also Imperial Japan and Imperial America.

    Sir, the P.A.P. also said during the last election - Sir, I am quoting from "Speakers' Notes" printed by the P.A.P. Propaganda Committee.

    Mr Speaker: I hope there is no confusion in the mind of any Member. "Speakers' Notes" do not mean the Speaker's notes.

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: Sir, the title of these Notes says "Speakers' Notes on Trade Unions" and not your notes.

    Mr Speaker: Was that a pamphlet which was published for the use of the public?

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: No.

    Mr Speaker: Well, then, the hon. Member is completely wrong in quoting from those notes if they are only notes, but he can paraphrase, of course.

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: Sir, these notes were published for P.A.P. Assemblymen to speak during the general elections.

    Some hon. Members: Oh!

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): Give me a copy!

    Mr Speaker: That is probably a very desirable objective. But what I am indicating is that those notes cannot be quoted verbatim in this Assembly. What the hon. Member can do is just to paraphrase. Say this is what the Member was asked to say.

Column: 2594



    Mr Teo Hock Guan: Sir, the P.A.P. said during the election that the right of dismissal should not be absolute. The employer must give just and reasonable grounds before sacking an employee. The P.A.P. has now become the Government and has also become the employer of Government servants. It sacks the staff of the People's Association, parking attendants, school servants, members of the Work Brigade, without giving any reasons. Sir, is it just and reasonable, as the P.A.P. Government calls it?

    The P.A.P. also said, "We will strengthen the trade unions by legislating for compulsory recognition of unions and cancellation of yellow unions." Sir, where is the legislation? The P.A.P. blamed the S.P.A. and the colonial regime for not taking care of our youth except to educate them to respect the colonial power. It also said that no effort was made to encourage and educate youth to take a serious interest in our social and political problems, for that was the last thing a colonial and reactionary government wanted. In 2½ years of office, has the P.A.P. Government made any change? No. Not the slightest change, Sir. It follows the colonial and S.P.A. style of work. Does the P.A.P. Government encourage our youth to take an interest in political problems, in that when they apply for government jobs they have to be questioned by Government officers which political Parties they join? Is that the way to encourage our youths, when they want to apply for jobs as teachers? Or if they wish to be elected to sit on the school management committee they have to face Government officers and answer in what past political events they have participated? Sir, this is the way to suppress the thinking of our youth and not to encourage it.

    Sir, the P.A.P. Government is very fond of accusing other people of causing trouble, but it is itself who is making trouble. The P.A.P. Government cannot fulfil its promise made in the last general elections. The P.A.P. Government said - and I quote, Sir, from the notes.

Column: 2595



    Mr Speaker: "Speakers' Notes"?

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: Yes.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I have already indicated that the hon. Member cannot quote from those notes. He can paraphrase them.

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: Sir, the P.A.P. said, as long as the Government of the Federation continues to ignore the existence of Nanyang University, although 60 per cent of its students are from the Federation, the Singapore Government will have to bear the financial burden of maintaining two Universities, i.e., the University of Singapore and Nanyang University. This is what the P.A.P. promised during the elections and this promise can be fulfilled without difficulty, but the P.A.P. Government does not want to do that. Instead it asks for unreasonable demands from Nanyang University. The Government attempts, in many ways, to interfere with the autonomy of Nan Ta and prevent its progress, because it refuses to give financial aid on the one hand and, on the other hand, it criticises the academic standard of Nan Ta without giving any help. Sir, the problems of recognising Nan Ta degrees and granting financial aid to Nanyang University have been purposely delayed and prolonged. The Government must realise that it has contributed nothing to the construction and expansion of Nanyang University. Therefore, the Government cannot cry for unreasonable demands from this University. Equal treatment will also be judged by the way the Government is going to solve the problems of Nan Ta. The Government must open classes for non-English school students in the Singapore Polytechnic. The other languages should also be used as media of instruction. This is part of the equal treatment, Sir.

    Sir, the curriculum in the English secondary schools has been designed to dovetail with the Cambridge School Certificate and the Higher School Certificate examinations. These examinations are set by a foreign examination syndicate to suit the educational

Column: 2596
